0.text: According to the American Psychological Association, praise — especially when it focuses on effort rather than outcome — helps develop a stable sense of self-worth. It supports a more positive self-view and reduces the fear of failure.
0.fact: J. K. Rowling, the author of "Harry Potter", often recalls that it was the support and praise from her literature teachers at school that helped her believe in her writing abilities, despite difficulties in her personal life and numerous rejections from publishers at the beginning of her career.

1.text: Psychological resilience plays a key role in how people respond to failures and obstacles. Studies show that people with high resilience continue to feel their own worth even after setbacks, which helps them recover more quickly and move forward.
1.fact: In Stoic philosophy, one of the central ideas is the ability to maintain inner calm and a sense of dignity despite external circumstances. Stoics such as Seneca and Marcus Aurelius taught that a person’s true value is determined not by successes and failures, but by their inner qualities and moral principles.

2.text: Research from Harvard Business School has shown that people who treat negative feedback as an opportunity for growth demonstrate significantly higher performance in their careers. One study found that 72% of employees who received constructive feedback improved their professional skills and productivity within a year.
2.fact: Bill Gates, the founder of Microsoft, has repeatedly emphasized that one of the reasons for his success is his ability to accept negative feedback and critically assess his actions. He believes that constructive criticism helps reveal weaknesses and improve productivity.

3.text: In psychology there is a concept called the “halo effect”, where one positive trait of a person, such as success or attractiveness, leads us to perceive them as more valuable in many other areas. This cognitive distortion often results in unfair evaluations of people.
3.fact: In different eras and societies, a person’s value has been judged by different criteria: origin, wealth, achievements, or moral qualities. For example, in aristocratic societies people from higher classes were considered “more valuable” purely because of their birth. This led to social inequality and discrimination.

4.text: The concept of a “growth mindset”, proposed by psychologist Carol Dweck, states that people with this mindset see mistakes and failures as opportunities for learning and development. Such people usually don’t let mistakes define their self-esteem and keep moving forward despite temporary difficulties.
4.fact: Steve Jobs, the founder of Apple, went through a major failure when he was fired from his own company. However, he did not allow this mistake to change his attitude toward himself. Instead, he founded a new company, which eventually brought him back to Apple, where he created some of the most successful products in history.

5.text: Self-reflection is the process of thinking about one’s actions, feelings, and motives. A study from the University of Colorado found that about 60% of people regularly wonder whether they are good or bad as a person.
5.fact: Moral ambivalence is the idea that both good and bad sides coexist in every person. Psychologists note that accepting this duality can help people come to terms with inner conflicts and stop obsessing over moral judgments about themselves.

6.text: Psychologists note that for many people self-esteem is closely tied to how they are seen by others, especially by significant others (family, friends, partners). A study from the University of Houston found that around 70% of people admit that their sense of self-worth increases when they feel loved and supported by important people in their lives.
6.fact: According to attachment theory, developed by John Bowlby, people with secure attachment in childhood (when they felt loved and protected) later develop a more stable sense of self-worth. Those who experienced a lack of love and attachment often feel a strong need for external recognition to compensate for this deficit.

7.text: Research shows that achieving goals can indeed lead to a short-term increase in happiness, but this effect is often temporary. A study from the University of Rochester found that after achieving a goal, happiness levels tend to return to their baseline within a few months. This phenomenon is known as “hedonic adaptation”.
7.fact: Jim Carrey, the well-known actor and comedian, has shared that even though he achieved all his career goals, it did not make him truly happy. He noted that happiness depends not only on external accomplishments, but also on one’s inner state and the ability to enjoy the present moment.

8.text: Philosophy often explores what makes a person “good”. One approach is virtue ethics, proposed by Aristotle, which states that a person is considered good if they cultivate virtues in different areas of life. However, this requires constant work on oneself and does not guarantee that success in one domain automatically means virtue in all others.
8.fact: People are complex and multifaceted, and success or virtue in one area does not necessarily mean virtue in every aspect of life. Studies indicate that personality traits and moral characteristics can vary greatly depending on context and situation.

9.text: Basing self-worth on comparison with others can lead to what is called “contingent self-esteem”, when a sense of worth depends strongly on external factors such as approval or success. This can create unstable self-esteem that fluctuates with circumstances and social environment.
9.fact: Social media amplifies the tendency for social comparison by creating the illusion of “perfect lives” in other people. Research shows that frequent use of social networks is associated with lower self-esteem, especially among adolescents and young adults. This happens because people tend to compare their real lives with carefully curated and edited images and achievements of others.

10.text: Unconditional self-acceptance is the idea that a person acknowledges their inherent worth regardless of external circumstances, achievements, or other people’s opinions.
10.fact: Martin Luther King Jr., a prominent leader of the civil rights movement, emphasized that all people are equal and have inherent value regardless of race, religion, or social status. His famous “I Have a Dream” speech reflected his belief that all people deserve equal respect and recognition simply because they are human.

11.text: People often use psychological defense mechanisms when receiving negative feedback because it can threaten their self-esteem. One common reaction to criticism is “defensive behavior”, when a person tries to justify themselves or reject the criticism in order to preserve their sense of self-worth. Studies show that this reaction is found in about 60–70% of people.
11.fact: Mark Twain, the famous writer, was known for his vivid reaction to criticism. He once said, “I can live for two months on a good compliment.” This highlights how strongly praise and criticism can influence a person’s self-perception and how hard it sometimes is to accept negative feedback.

12.text: Many people set goals in order to prove their worth — to themselves and to others. This relates to the concept of “contingent self-esteem”, when a sense of dignity depends on achievements and recognition. Studies show that about 40% of people in Western cultures are often motivated by this desire to prove their value.
12.fact: Contingent self-esteem can be unstable because it depends on reaching goals and receiving recognition. People whose self-esteem rests on external factors often experience emotional ups and downs and anxiety when they fail to achieve their goals. At the same time, reaching these goals can temporarily boost their self-esteem.

13.text: People with perfectionistic tendencies often link their value to success in particular areas. Research shows that perfectionists experience strong feelings of inadequacy and a drop in self-esteem if they fail to meet their high standards. Around 30% of people with pronounced perfectionism suffer from anxiety disorders and depression because they cannot accept their failures.
13.fact: John Kennedy Toole, the author of "A Confederacy of Dunces", long considered himself a failure because he could not get his novel published. This greatly affected his self-esteem and ultimately led to tragic consequences. After his death, however, the novel was published and became a bestseller, winning the Pulitzer Prize — a reminder that failure in one area does not define the overall value of a person.

14.text: Viewing a person’s value mainly through the lens of success can create enormous pressure on those who try to meet very high standards. Research shows that striving for success purely to feel valuable in society’s eyes can lead to burnout and lower overall life satisfaction. This mindset can also reduce a person’s ability to accept failures and learn from them.
14.fact: Different cultures use different criteria to assess a person’s value, but in many Western societies professional success is a key marker of worth. Studies show that in individualistic cultures such as the USA and the UK, a person’s value is closely tied to career achievements. In more collectivist cultures, such as Japan or China, greater importance is placed on family and social connections.

15.text: Praise plays an important role in the development of self-awareness and self-esteem, especially when it focuses on specific achievements or qualities. Studies show that 82% of people consider praise an effective way to learn about their strengths and develop them. Praise that points to concrete actions or traits helps people recognize their talents and use them for further growth.
15.fact: Vincent van Gogh, despite difficulties and a lack of understanding from others, received encouraging feedback from his brother Theo, which helped him see his strengths as an artist. This support kept Van Gogh going on his creative path despite constant doubts and hardships.

16.text: Inner self-esteem is a person’s ability to feel worthy regardless of external approval or other people’s opinions. Psychologists note that people with strong inner self-esteem depend less on others’ views and cope better with criticism.
16.fact: Eleanor Roosevelt, First Lady of the United States, faced harsh criticism for her active public role and political involvement. Despite this, she remained true to her principles and continued to fight for human rights, stating: “No one can make you feel inferior without your consent.”

17.text: People who avoid comparing themselves to others more often develop healthy self-esteem and confidence. This allows them to better understand their own values and achievements without needing external confirmation of their significance.
17.fact: A study from the University of Michigan found that people who avoid comparing themselves to others are 30% less likely to experience depression and anxiety. They are also 40% more likely to report high life satisfaction and self-esteem. This confirms that stepping away from social comparison supports better psychological well-being.

18.text: Criticism can have a strong impact on self-esteem, especially if a person experiences it as a personal attack rather than constructive feedback. Studies show that about 70% of people experience a drop in self-esteem after being criticized, particularly when the criticism comes from someone important to them. This happens because people tend to internalise negative comments, which can lead to self-criticism and reduced confidence.
18.fact: Cognitive distortions such as “all-or-nothing thinking” and “overgeneralisation” can intensify the negative impact of criticism. For example, a person may start to think that if they failed at one task, they are a failure in general. This distortion can sharply lower self-esteem and undermine confidence in their abilities.

19.text: In philosophy there is an idea that every person has inherent, inalienable worth that does not depend on their actions, successes, or others’ opinions. This concept is especially emphasized in humanistic psychology, where founders such as Carl Rogers and Abraham Maslow argued that a person’s value should be taken as a given, not something to be rated or compared.
19.fact: Mahatma Gandhi often said that a person’s worth cannot be measured or diminished by others. He believed that everyone deserves respect and dignity regardless of their status or achievements, and this belief became the foundation of his philosophy of nonviolence and struggle for equality.

low.text: Your answers suggest that you tend to be strict with yourself and often link your value to achievements and others’ evaluations. Mistakes and failures may feel especially painful and lead to a drop in self-esteem. In such moments it can seem as if your worth depends on external circumstances rather than on you as a person. Developing skills of self-acceptance and a kinder attitude toward yourself can help you feel more stable and less dependent on external criticism.
low.title: Lack of self-acceptance

middle.text: Your answers show that you are generally able to accept yourself, but at times you experience fluctuations in self-esteem. In some situations you feel confident, while in others you may feel vulnerable to criticism and other people’s opinions. Sometimes your sense of worth may be tied to achievements or external evaluations, which affects your emotional state. At the same time, you already have a solid foundation for developing more stable self-acceptance. Practising mindfulness and a kind attitude toward yourself can strengthen your confidence and help you stay steady through different periods of life.
middle.title: Moderate self-acceptance

high.text: Your answers indicate a high level of self-acceptance and inner confidence. You are able to maintain a sense of self-worth regardless of external evaluations and circumstances. You treat mistakes and difficulties calmly, with understanding and respect for yourself. External criticism and comparison with others have little impact on your state, because you rely on inner resources and have a clear sense of your own value. This attitude helps you build healthy relationships, feel internally stable, and live in harmony with yourself.
high.title: Inner harmony

text: In a world full of external expectations and constant comparisons, it can be difficult to maintain confidence in your own worth and uniqueness. Inner self-acceptance becomes an important support and foundation for a harmonious life.
This questionnaire will help you understand how you relate to yourself, how you respond to criticism, and what your self-esteem is based on.
Take the test to find out how deeply you accept yourself and how strongly you support your inner sense of value.
